unnormalised: The other day, I was helping my grandmother, Nirmala Devi, with her banking. Dadi, as we fondly call her, has always been a bit hesitant about online transactions. She prefers the old-fashioned way – physically going to the State Bank of India branch in our locality in Patna. But with the long queues and her increasing difficulty in getting around, I decided it was time to introduce her to the world of digital banking, slowly but surely.
normalised: The other day, I was helping my grandmother, Nirmala Devi, with her banking. Dadi, as we fondly call her, has always been a bit hesitant about online transactions. She prefers the old-fashioned way – physically going to the State Bank of India branch in our locality in Patna. But with the long queues and her increasing difficulty in getting around, I decided it was time to introduce her to the world of digital banking, slowly but surely.

unnormalised: Her main concern was understanding her bank statement. She’d received the latest one in the mail, and it was filled with all sorts of cryptic abbreviations and numbers that made absolutely no sense to her. "Beta," she sighed, handing me the sheet, "what is all this nonsense? 'NEFT credit', 'UPI debit', 'IMPS transfer' – it’s all Greek to me!"
normalised: Her main concern was understanding her bank statement. She’d received the latest one in the mail, and it was filled with all sorts of cryptic abbreviations and numbers that made absolutely no sense to her. "Beta," she sighed, handing me the sheet, "what is all this nonsense? 'N-E-F-T credit', 'U-P-I debit', 'I-M-P-S transfer' – it’s all Greek to me!"

unnormalised: So, I sat down with Dadi, chai in hand, and started explaining. The first transaction was a “Cr” for Rs. 5000. I explained this was a credit, meaning money added to her account. Turns out, it was her pension that she receives on the 1st of every month. Next, was "Dr" for Rs. 2000 which was deducted on 15/07/2024. She was worried sick. Turns out this was the amount she paid to the cable guy the previous month and he had deposited the cheque only now!
normalised: So, I sat down with Dadi, chai in hand, and started explaining. The first transaction was a “Credit” for rupee five thousand. I explained this was a credit, meaning money added to her account. Turns out, it was her pension that she receives on the first of every month. Next, was "Debit" for rupee two thousand which was deducted on fifteenth july two thousand and twenty four. She was worried sick. Turns out this was the amount she paid to the cable guy the previous month and he had deposited the cheque only now!

unnormalised: Then there was a series of “UPI Debits” for small amounts: Rs. 50, Rs. 100, Rs. 25, all to different vendors. I had to explain to her what UPI even was, and how she must've unknowingly authorised small payment requests. Dadi was shocked that it was this simple! "Imagine paying the rickshaw-walla using my phone!", she exclaimed. "That would be revolutionary!".

unnormalised: We then came across a transaction labeled “ATM WDL” for Rs. 10000 on 20/06/2024. Dadi looked confused. “But I haven’t taken out any money recently!” After a little probing, it turned out my uncle, Suresh, had borrowed her ATM card to withdraw some cash. I promised Dadi we would have a stern talking to with Suresh about using her card without informing her first.

I promised Dadi we would have a stern talking to with Suresh about using her card without informing her first.

unnormalised: The statement also showed a “SB Interest” of Rs. 345.67 credited to her account. This was the interest earned on her savings account balance. Dadi was pleasantly surprised! She hadn't even known she was earning interest. Another entry was "AMC charges Dr" for Rs. 250. This was an annual maintenance fee that the bank levies for maintaining her account. Dadi grumbled a bit about hidden charges, but I assured her it was a standard practice.

unnormalised: Finally, we tackled the most confusing entry: "RTGS transfer Dr" for Rs. 1,00,000 on 01/07/2024. Turns out, this was the money she had sent to her granddaughter, Priya, for her college fees. But the abbreviation had completely baffled her.

unnormalised: By the end of our “banking lesson,” Dadi felt much more comfortable with her statement. She still prefers going to the bank for larger transactions, but she’s now open to exploring UPI for smaller payments, maybe even learn to transfer money online. All thanks to me and my explanation of 'Cr', 'Dr', 'UPI', and all the other financial jargon that had initially seemed so intimidating to her! The SBI manager at the local branch, Mr. Sharma, would be quite happy to see her less often.
